video.title: How I scaled the world’s largest music studio marketplace (part 2 of the Studiotime story)
video.description:
Mike continues his story of how he scaled Studiotime (http://www.studiotime.io) from an MVP to the largest online marketplace for music studios in the world. He discusses the tools he used to do so without building a custom platform (Wordpress, Sharetribe, Chargebee, Stripe, Zapier, and Slack). 

Make sure to watch part 1: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IZGlnImsrxc

Resources shared in this video:

Sharetribe (marketplace platform): http://bit.ly/2gXICOV
Wordpress (landing pages): http://www.wordpress.com
Chargebee (subscriptions): http://bit.ly/2zZvfVP
Stripe (payments): http://www.stripe.com
Zapier (task automation & integrations): http://www.zapier.com
Slack (integrations & notifications): http://www.slack.com

topLevelComment.author: Shelley Thompson
topLevelComment.text: Thank you for sharing all this knowledge. Its awesome, and to hear how you have utilized all these platforms to run your product so successfully is giving me hope. You rock.

topLevelComment.author: Shelley Thompson
topLevelComment.text: How did you then develop the mobile apps? Can users rate studios and vice versa? How much coding knowledge do you have?

replies.author: Mike Williams
replies.text:
The mobile apps were wrappers, so not at all difficult. Most of the traffic for Studiotime is desktop, so there isn't a huge need to go full native with apps right now (which would be optimal). I'll probably do native app builds in a few months though. 

Regarding the reviews, both the person that books (artists) and studios (provider) leave reviews following a booking.

topLevelComment.author: Creative Rod
topLevelComment.text: Question: When a user chooses a subscription and pays thru chargebee how do you determine what access they have?

replies.author: Mike Williams
replies.text: Correct, I get a notification and can edit user access at that point. I try to make sure other studios (for instance photo studios) don't pay and try to list or people do the same to list their services. This has happened in the past and I simply refund and send them an email letting them know Studiotime is not ideal for their use case at this time since we're just focused on music studios (for now). I've found that there needs to be some manual quality control/review.
